'Tis vain to muse — no more the pitying thought,</br>Nursed in the bosom of soft sympathy,</br>Shall rise in fond solicitude — the note</br>Of harmony shall sound no more — with me</br>The sounds of jarring discord best agree;</br>The oppressor's triumph, and the poor man's wrong,</br>With jaundiced eye and stern delight I see;</br>Vain is the aid of lute or soothing song,</br>I have no future hope — no fears to me belong.

And what art thou?  A man — why so am I—</br>A rich one — so I was — though now as poor</br>E'en as the veriest wretch that e'er passed by,</br>Or begged a meagre pittance at thy door.</br>Yet though my couch is but this rocky floor,</br>Secluded from the worldling's idle gaze,</br>And fearing not the iron hand of power,</br>More true content I feel, than in those days</br>When fortune shed on me her brightest, richest rays.
More true content!  alas!  I know it not—</br>———*———*———*———*———*———</br>———*———*———*———*———*———

One eve I stood upon the rocky shore,</br>And marked with joy the gathering clouds of night,</br>And listening to the ocean's sullen roar,</br>I hailed the coming storm with fierce delight—</br>And though no living object met my sight,</br>Yet could I hear the sea-bird's piercing scream,</br>As o'er the foaming surge it came, whilst bright</br>At intervals the lightning's forky flame</br>Parted through night's dark vault with sudden, vivid gleam.

Then came the thunder of a distant gun,</br>Heard indistinctly o'er the roaring wave;</br>Another came, a nearer, louder one—</br>But in that hour no human aid could save;</br>Each boiling billow oped a yawning grave,</br>Gaping expectant of its destined prey;</br>To it were all alike — the fair — the brave—</br>Who but that morn had been all joyous — gay—</br>The waves that night engulphed — remorseless swept away.

Then came a sight of horror — o'er the surge</br>A little skiff came bounding — with firm stroke</br>Their onward course the sturdy rowers urge,</br>And almost touch the shore, when 'gainst a rock</br>Their slender bark was driven with fatal shock,</br>And all were plunged beneath the briny foam—</br>The screaming peterel, hovering, seemed to mock</br>Their dying agonies — they thought of home</br>In vain — the ocean bed is their untimely tomb.

But they are happy — by that speedy death</br>Relieved, removed far from this world of pain</br>And griping misery, while their parting breath</br>Was consecrate on high — that death were gain—</br>Soul-harrowing thought — and I must live — a stain,</br>A mark to all — Oh!  that I could shake off</br>The trammels of this life — my soul regain</br>Her pristine purity — aye!  thou may'st scoff,</br>But I may reckless bear the scorner's jeering laugh.

Oh!  Anna!  fairest, purest, loveliest, best—</br>Yes, thou wast all to me — thy angel mind</br>The seat of every virtue — in thy breast</br>Was worth with sportive innocence combined—</br>And thou art gone — What!  must I be resigned</br>Ah no!  I cannot — yet I cannot weep—</br>And must my griefs be to myself confined</br>And must this heart no more her image keep!</br>It shall be so — when I am wrapt in endless sleep.

Days, weeks, months, years, passed on — I saw thee not—</br>And thou wast as one dead to me — to live</br>Alone in my remembrance, unforgot</br>Whilst time endures — a dreary prospective—</br>And my full heart was left alone — to grieve</br>O'er dreams of other days, when wanton Joy</br>On silken pinions came but to deceive,</br>And spoke of happiness without alloy,</br>To last while Life endured — which Time could ne'er destroy.

The dream of days had vanished — I returned,</br>And saw thee once again — still thou wast fair,</br>Aye, fairer than when first my passion burned—</br>The roseate vermeil of thy cheeks was there,</br>And it was richer, purer, and more clear</br>Than when I first beheld thee — but the glow</br>Of ruddy health was fled — thy breath was sere—</br>The current in thy veins ran sluggish — slow—</br>And fled the cheerful smile — the spirits jocund flow.

And still thine eyes of beaming blue were bright,</br>Those radiant orbs which oft in happier hours</br>Have o'er my inmost soul shed sweet delight—</br>Yes, bright as when through * * * leafy bowers</br>We strayed at silent eve, or mid the flowers</br>On that green bank reposed, while parting day</br>In softened splendour, gilt the ancient towers</br>Of Musgrave's castle with a crimson ray,</br>And unperceived by us stole on the twilight grey.

I saw thee yet again — the vermeil blush</br>Had vanished from thy cheek — thy glancing eye</br>Had lost it's lustre — and the sickly flush</br>Of pale disease was there — yet not a sigh</br>Of pain escaped thee, but thou wast as I</br>Should wish to be, resigned, in faith secure</br>And though it is a painful thing to die,</br>That pain with constancy thou could'st endure—</br>Thy pilgrimage was short, but thy reward is sure.

Spirits of happiness!  which hover round</br>The peaceful mansions of the blest, where nought</br>Of sorrow can approach, let the soft sound</br>Of your ethereal harps be hither brought,</br>And let them utter each soul-soothing note,</br>To lull my wounded spirit to repose;</br>That as their strains around me gently float,</br>My heart to calm content they may dispose,</br>And Death steal on at last like sober evening's close.</br>
